7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:12): so what would be amiss, if the second type of image just went away ? if the answer is "something", it should (semantically) be viewed as content (and thus probably have an alt text ?). if the answer is "nothing", then images of this type are deco, or aren't they ?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:21): the only reason to put these in html rather than css is conveniene

7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i believe this should be discouraged. i mean, i remember people who laid out tables "for convenience" ...

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:47): using tables for layout causes harm, because it makes the page less accessible, in that the page doesn't represent the actual structure of the page, and pretends to use a data table when it does not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:47): these problems don't occur with using <img> for one-off purely decorative images
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:48): that's right, indeed.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:50): but the semantic value tends to be zero and that makes me somehow uneasy.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:50): (my table analogy was only from a pure semantic POV, not from a practical accessability one)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:51): i agree that using css for this should be encouraged
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:52): but there's no reason to make this more complicated for authors than necessary just for purity
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:55): well, it makes the rules more complicated, but it certainly is a viable solution for those who don't need the flexibility provided by CSS.
